The use of force feedback and auditory cues for performance of an assembly task in an immersive virtual environment
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 25 March 2004

The use of force feedback and auditory cues for performance of an assembly task in an immersive virtual environment

  • Gregory W. Edwards1,
  • Woodrow Barfield2 &
  • Maury A. Nussbaum3 

Virtual Reality volume 7, pages112–119(2004)Cite this article

  • 229 Accesses

  • 9 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Using an immersive virtual environment, this study investigated whether the inclusion of force feedback or auditory cues improved manipulation performance and subjective reports of usability for an assembly task. Twenty-four volunteers (12 males and 12 females) were required to assemble and then disassemble five interconnecting virtual parts with either auditory, force, or no feedback cues provided. Performance for the assembly task was measured using completion time and number of collisions between parts, while the users’ preferences across conditions were evaluated using subjective reports of usability. The results indicated that the addition of force feedback slowed completion time and led to more collisions between parts for males. In contrast, females exhibited no change in the mean completion time for the assembly task but did show an increase in collision counts. Despite these negative performance findings when adding force feedback, users did report perceived increases in realism, helpfulness and utility towards the assembly task when force feedback was provided. Unlike force feedback, the results showed that auditory feedback, indicating that parts had collided during the assembly task, had no negative performance effects on the objective measures while still increasing perceived realism and overall user satisfaction. When auditory cues and force feedback were presented together, performance times, number of collisions, and usability were not improved compared to conditions containing just auditory cues or force feedback alone. Based on these results, and given the task and display devices used in the present study, the less costly option of excluding auditory and force feedback cues would produce the best performance when measured by the number of collisions and completion time. However, if increased ratings of usability for an assembly task are desired while maintaining objective performance levels and reduced cost, then the inclusion of auditory feedback cues is best.

Introduction

In a typical virtual environment (VE) application, the user receives stereoscopic imagery and auditory cues (sometimes localised), and less often force feedback cues. Rarely will the user be provided with olfactory or gustatory simulation [3, 4]. The lack of touch in many current VEs or, as it is often referred to in the literature, haptic stimulation, has been mainly due to device costs, limitations associated with the technology [3], and the difficulties in integrating realistic haptic interactions with the correct physics of the scene and control dynamics of the force feedback devices. Yet, with the recent commercialisation of new haptic technologies and software development platforms (e.g., GHOST from Sensable, LHX [19] and G2H [1]), the simulation of force feedback in VEs is starting to become more widespread.

A question now faced by many VE developers is whether the cost and associated effort of integrating the current haptic devices into a computer-generated simulation are worthwhile. In certain situations, such as training fine motor skills for surgeons, it has been shown that the use of haptic feedback improved performance [29, 33]. On the other hand, it is less certain whether tasks involving more gross motor skills, such as industrial assembly tasks, would benefit from haptic feedback. Given the widespread use of auditory cues in VEs and the limitations with current haptic technologies, one design alternative could be to use auditory cues as a substitute for information typically presented through the sense of touch. For example, auditory cues could be used to provide collision information readily detected by the haptic modality, thus extending the idea of sensory substitution prevalent in rehabilitation medicine to the VE domain [2, 20]. Along these lines, the purpose of this research was to investigate whether auditory cues would be as effective as force feedback cues (the kinesthetic subset of haptic cues) for an assembly task and whether subjective evaluations of usability would differ as a function of the type of feedback information provided to the user when performing a task within a VE.

Background

Force feedback and auditory substitution

Earlier work in the haptic simulation field began with telerobotics and focused on allowing operators to feel the forces exerted on remote robots [12, 33]. Later, with advances in VE technology and computer graphics, force feedback research was undertaken in an attempt to increase the realism and interactivity of VE applications. To evaluate performance, the early studies in this field focused on objective measures of accuracy and time to completion. For example, for simple pick and place tasks, time to completion was shown to either improve with the addition of force feedback [32] or to not improve at all [13]. Position accuracy, however, was shown to increase with force feedback in both the previously mentioned studies. During peg-in-hole insertion tasks, studies routinely produced widely varying results. For example, with two and three degree of freedom (DOF) tasks, force feedback has led to between 0% and 200% reductions in completion times [6, 13, 15, 17, 24]. These varying results are likely due to the different levels of the simulation’s fidelity, different display update rates and display technologies, different subject populations and the particular training given or the specific type of feedback device that was employed.

There are several factors that make incorporating force feedback into VEs difficult. These include the high costs for devices with higher degrees of freedom (DOF) and the limited amount of fidelity provided with current haptic devices (e.g., very few can provide force feedback with six DOF in real time). Another issue is the large processing requirements and slow update rates of current devices; reducing realism and once again increasing costs and availability of haptic devices to the general public. Finally, most devices can only provide one main type of haptic feedback, either kinesthetic (force feedback) or tactile sensations. Due to these limitations, many VE developers have also investigated other methods of providing spatial information, one of the more popular methods being the use of auditory cues [16].

However, the use of sound in VEs to assist in performance has also produced inconsistent results. For example, some past studies on the use of sound in VEs have shown that sound reduced completion times by close to 50% for a pick and place task (equal to the performance gained by the addition of haptic cues); other studies showed sound helping, but less than force feedback [32], or not helping at all [13, 24]. For both cases where sound did not improve performance, users and investigators indicated that there was either too much sound, leading to operator overload, or not enough sound [13, 24].

Gender, spatial ability and fine motor skills

Gender, spatial ability and fine motor skills are three potentially confounding factors that studies should consider when collecting performance measures requiring spatial judgments in VEs. In many situations, tasks that are performed by subjects within VEs require the interpretation of the spatial relationships between objects within the scene. Typical applied spatial tasks include determining distances between objects, estimating depth relationships, or estimating the size of objects contained within a scene. Differences in spatial ability according to gender have been widely cited in the literature across a range of spatial tasks [7, 22, 26, 30, 35, 37]. One popular method of measuring spatial ability, the mental rotation task, has reported consistent results of males performing better than females [8, 23, 36]. Given these gender differences, it would be of interest to designers of VEs to determine if males and females performed differently as a function of a particular spatial task performed within a VE. However, many of the past investigations into the effects of spatial ability, relating specifically to VE performance, have been specifically related to navigational performance in large VEs and not manipulation tasks. These studies have found mixed results with spatial ability tests sometimes showing positive correlations with navigational performance and sometimes not [10, 34].

Many studies that have examined gender differences on fine motor skill ability (i.e., manipulation tasks) concluded that, in contrast to gross motor skill tasks, females generally perform better [27, 28]. The most notable differences have been observed during a peg-in-hole insertion task. Recently, however, an alternate explanation for the performance differences was proposed by [27]. Using an insertion task, finger and thumb size were measured for all participants, and then considered in the statistical analysis of performance. Interestingly, including finger size as a covariate eliminated any gender differences, suggesting that the faster performance was a result of finger size rather than gender. The results of a study by [21] provided additional evidence for this finding; with a similar peg-in-hole insertion task that used larger pegs with 9.5 mm diameters, males were faster than females. Based on the above mentioned studies, it is less clear whether in fact a difference exists between genders in fine motor skill ability and if so, what is the nature of that difference. Thus, it is uncertain whether gender or spatial ability may have an effect on manipulation ability in VEs, and for this reason, both variables were monitored in this study.

Methods

Research objectives

The research described in this paper had four main objectives. The first objective was to determine whether force feedback increased performance and ease of interaction for a simulated assembly task performed within an immersive VE. Secondly, the study sought to determine whether force feedback cues made the interactions more realistic for the user and potentially allowed them to do their task more proficiently. Thirdly, the study sought to determine whether auditory cues provided an effective substitute for force feedback. And fourthly, the study sought to establish whether having both auditory and force feedback cues would increase performance and subjective measures of user satisfaction, given that this condition provided the most sensory stimulation and potentially the most realistic condition of those provided in the study.

The experimental design

Twenty-four volunteers (12 males and 12 females) between the ages of 18 and 45 participated in this 2 x2 x 2 mixed factorial design with gender as the between subject factor and force feedback (with or without) along with audio feedback (with or without) being the within subject factors. Participation was limited to individuals without extensive previous VE experience, and due to the manipulation of a force feedback device, subjects who indicated any wrist problems were excluded from the study. For the four within feedback conditions (sound x haptics), the order of presentation of treatments was determined using three balanced Latin squares. In order to attain a reliable response measure at each condition, based on the results of two pilot studies [9], it was determined that an initial practice session as well as four trials at each condition were required.

Equipment and software

The VE was generated using an Intergraph Pentium II workstation with 128 MB of RAM, a MultiRealiZm Z13-GT graphics card with 16 MB of frame buffer memory and 32 MB of texture memory, and an on-board Crystal CS4236B 16-bit sound controller. The software used to develop the virtual environment was WorldToolKit release 8 (patch 5) from Sense8, Microsoft Visual C++ 6.0 and Ghost SDK version 3.0 for the haptics. Graphics were viewed using a V8 head-mounted display (HMD), from Virtual Research Systems, with a resolution of 640×480 pixels and a 60° diagonal field of view (FOV). Non-localized sound was produced using the Sennheiser HD25 headphones on the V8. Lastly, force feedback interaction was provided through the Sensable technologies PHANToM 1.5A Haptic Interface using the stylus attachment.

The task and the VE

The experiment task consisted of disassembling a system of parts, replacing one part and then reconstructing the system. There were seven differently sized, weighted, shaped and colored parts (Fig. 1) representing a mechanical assembly modeled after a real assembly task as illustrated in [5]. Participants were required to manipulate three-dimensional objects rapidly and with accuracy. Each participant completed the task four times with each feedback condition (no extra feedback, sound, force feedback, force feedback and sound). Upon donning the HMD the user saw a workbench, the part system, the additional part used for replacement, a barrier around the part system (to simulate that the system was part of a larger mechanical assembly), and a cursor used for manipulation. The manipulation of the components was done through the stylus attachment of the PHANToM force feedback device, with the movements of the real-world stylus corresponding to the position of the virtual cursor in the VE. When the cursor touched a component within the VE, the user was able to grasp the object by pressing the button on the stylus. Keeping the button depressed while moving the cursor had the effect of dragging the part with the cursor. By letting go of the button, the part could then be dropped.

To assemble two particular parts together, the user was first required to manipulate the parts into the correct orientation using the PHANToM input device. Next the subject was required to push the two parts together in order to perform the assembly task. The user received feedback that the two parts were connected, i.e., assembled, through either visual feedback (the flashing of the parts) or a clicking sound (if sounds were enabled; more details are given in Table 1). The same procedure was used for disconnecting parts.

Force feedback in this experiment refers to force feedback sensed through the end of the stylus pointing device on the PHANToM, but with the added ability to create simulated surface friction. A peak force of 10 N can be returned by the PHANToM, with a maximum continuous output of 1.5 N. This amount of force realistically simulates what people sense in typical manipulation tasks in industrial settings for small to medium-sized consumer parts. Auditory feedback was presented to both ears (but not localised or head tracked) through headphones and produced by prerecorded samples that were replayed through a standard 16-bit sound card. The auditory cues were used to convey information similar to the force feedback cues, but within the auditory modality. Thus, when two parts collided in the VE, a “metallic sound” occurred, indicating the collision.

Procedures and measures

Each participant began the experiment by filling out a background questionnaire on their prior computer and gaming experience and then completing a mental rotations test (MRT) [8] for a measure of their spatial ability. A study by [37] reported that the mean difference in standard deviations between men and women, for the psychometric test of mental rotation was 0.94, indicating that men perform nearly one standard deviation above the average performance of women.

Participants then interacted with a demo program in which they manipulated a single object using the PHANToM. A description of the task was provided, and participants were asked to complete four practice trials, one with each feedback condition. After all practice trials, the participant completed the task four times in each condition and then completed a questionnaire assessing perceived usability. Objective measures of performance included time to completion and the number of collisions made with the parts. A collision occurred any time an edge, corner or surface of the part being held crossed any other surface, edge or corner (for a part not held by the subject). Subjective measures included a usability questionnaire administered after each condition, composed of six 10-point rating scales on: overall reaction, ease of use, realism, ease of learning, perceived system speed and perceived performance. A final questionnaire was also given to the participants after all conditions had been completed and was composed of rating scales comparing the conditions. During the course of the study, no participants experienced any symptoms of simulator sickness.

Results

Based on an analysis of the four trials during a pilot study, the data from the third and fourth trials were used to create a combined score for time to completion and number of collisions occurring during the assembly task [9].

Completion times

Based on an analysis of variance procedure (ANOVA), force feedback had a statistically significant effect on completion time for the assembly task (F 1,63=2.92, p < .05). As shown by Fig. 2, across subjects, performance times were slowest for the sound and force feedback condition and fastest for the condition lacking both these cues. Furthermore, the ANOVA found statistically significant differences in completion time performance as a function of gender; females completed the task more rapidly than males with mean completion times of 83.7 seconds versus 105.7 seconds (F 1,63=7.71, p< 0.01). In addition, an interaction between gender and force feedback was found (Fig. 3); with performance for males decreasing by 33.8% when force feedback was enabled (90.4 s no haptics v. 121.4 s haptics), but not significantly changing for females (85.9 s for no haptics v. 81.9 s for haptics) (F 1,63=4.91, p< 0.03).

Due to the gender interaction, the data for each gender was also analysed separately. Based on an ANOVA, males showed a statistically significant increase in performance time when using force feedback to complete the simulated assembly task (F 1,30 = 5.31, p < .03). For males, sound had no significant effect for completion times (F 1,30 = 0.48, p >.05); and for females there was no significant main effect for either sound (F 1,30=1.88, p >.05), or force feedback (F 1,30=0.30, p >.05).

The number of collisions

Based on multiple Wilcoxon Signed Ranks Tests, it was shown that force feedback had a significant effect on the collision counts for both genders. When force feedback was not present, both females and males had significantly lower collision counts in the order of 37% (females) and 59% (males) (T+ = 72.5> w(1-α/2=0.975) = 64, T+ = 78> w(1-α/2=0.975) = 64; Fig. 4). Further, based on the results of a Mann-Whitney test, a significant difference was measured between genders. Females made less collisions on average than males with counts of 33.5 versus 46.9 (T = 115.5< wp(α/2=0.025) = 116; Fig. 5).

The mental rotations test

Males scored significantly higher than females on the mental rotations test with mean scores (40 was perfect performance) of 22.2 (males) versus 18.9 (females) (X2 = 4.45, p< 0.04). However, no statistically significant correlations were found between the mental rotation test score and the response measures of time to completion (r = 0.05, p >.05), or number of collisions made during the virtual environment assembly task (r = -0.03, p >.05).

The between conditions questionnaire data

Sound, force feedback and order all had significant effects on the between condition questionnaire data. Using the Mann-Whitney test, it was found that the addition of force feedback created higher user satisfaction ratings (U = 134.5, n= 18, w(1-a/2=0.975) = 130, higher ratings of realism (Uforce_feedback= 178.5, n= 20, w(1-a/2=0.975) = 157) and higher ease of learning ratings (U = 148, n= 19, w(1-a/2=0.975) = 143). The addition of sound on the other hand only created significantly higher ratings for realism (Usound = 164.5, n= 20, w(1-a/2=0.975) = 157). While not statistically significant, there were also trends towards higher ratings for overall satisfaction and perceived simulation update rate when sound was present. A correlation analysis was done between the subject’s perceived level of performance and the participant’s average time and number of collisions. A statistically significant correlation was found for both measures, for average time and number of collisions respectively (r = -0.43 and 0.26, p < .01); indicating that participants were accurate in reporting how well they performed.

The post-questionnaire data

Gender and force feedback had significant effects on the user’s perception of helpfulness towards completing the task, and gender, force feedback and sound all had significant effects on the application’s perceived utility of usefulness towards a design task. For males, the force feedback condition led to higher ratings of helpfulness (X2 = 9.62, p = 0.02) and usefulness towards the assembly task (X2 = 21.94, p = 0.00). Females, on the other hand, when presented with force feedback in the conditions, only exhibited higher ratings for the question on helpfulness towards an assembly task (X2 = 15.66, p< 0.01). Although not statistically significant, the no feedback condition was ranked the overall worst condition.

Discussion

The research described in the current study was conducted with four objectives in mind. The first was to investigate whether force feedback increased performance and ease of interaction for a VE assembly task. The study showed that the addition of force feedback actually decreased performance and that there was no indicated change in ease of use based on the usability analysis. One possible explanation for these results is that the simulation was not realistic enough to benefit from force feedback given the limitations of the collision realism in the environment (slight vibrations on large multiple object collisions) and the particular force feedback device used in the study. It may be the case that by providing force feedback to the user through the stylus device as opposed to projecting forces onto the user’s entire hand may have led to insufficient force feedback to perform the assembly task at the level expected. If this were the case, then there may be some minimal level of realism required before force feedback begins to increase performance. Further research on this topic is required to determine whether this view is valid.

The second research question sought to determine whether force feedback cues made the interactions more realistic and could potentially allow users to gain more benefit from the simulation. The study found that males reported an increased sense of realism with the addition of force feedback, while females only showed a tendency to rank force feedback as more realistic. Neither gender ranked the force feedback condition significantly higher for realism, indicating only a small preference for force feedback. For hypothesised utility towards a design task, participants ranked the force feedback conditions higher than the non-force feedback conditions, indicating that after having used the system with and without force feedback, almost all participants believed that force feedback would be useful in a real design application.

The third objective of the study was to determine whether auditory cues provided an effective substitute for force feedback. Based on objective performance measures sound did not produce the negative effects that force feedback did; sound neither increased or decreased completion time or the number or collisions. Subjective measures of realism and overall satisfaction, on the other hand, were found to be equivalent for sound and force feedback. Thus, sound may be an effective means of conveying collision information, since sound did not negatively affect manipulation performance while still slightly increasing user-perceived realism and overall satisfaction. A downside, however, was that sound is not hypothesised to be as helpful as force feedback in a design scenario. This can be explained by user comments, which clearly indicated that users believed the force feedback condition presented more potentially useful information than sound.

The fourth research question focused on whether the combination of sound and force feedback led to increased user satisfaction or performance. While not improving performance based on the objective measures, the results indicated that participants rated the combination of sound and force feedback higher than all other conditions for perceived usefulness towards a real assembly task.

Gender differences

The main gender difference found in the study, which indicated that females performed the task using force feedback better than males, was unexpected. Previous studies on spatial ability have shown that males score higher in spatial ability when doing a psychometric test [8, 23, 36]. The mental rotation test results in the current study were consistent with previous findings, with males scoring significantly higher than females. However, there was no statistically significant correlation between the mental rotation test score and performance. In fact, manipulation ability appeared stronger for females than males with force feedback implemented, shown by significantly lower completion times and fewer collisions. Studies showing females to be superior in fine motor skill were supposedly due to the small size of the objects being manipulated and the smaller hand size of females [27]. However, in this experiment, the stylus on the PHANToM was 9.5 mm in diameter. This diameter was sufficiently large enough to reduce any hand size differences in manipulation ability [21, 27]. Thus, there may still be reason to believe that females do have superior fine motor skill abilities, which became apparent when force feedback was present in this study. It would seem that females were able to utilise the increased accuracy provided by force feedback more effectively than males, allowing females to balance out the increased number of collisions that force feedback contributed to. Based purely on informal observations it did seem to the researchers that females were more precise in their movements, shown by the decreased number of collisions.

In addition, there was also a gender learning difference that should be mentioned. The present finding does suggest that females were able to learn more from the task and improve their performance more over time than males (both genders started out approximately equivalent in performance on the first condition). Once again, this may lend credibility to females having superior fine motor skills despite the findings by [27]. Although this research sheds no new light on the reasons behind the dissimilarities, it does add another documented task with gender differences that may be subject to further studies to increase our understanding.

Design guidelines

The following design suggestions should be considered preliminary in nature due to limitations resulting from the specific variables, equipment, and subjects used in the study. The guidelines are presented to suggest areas where designers may decide to choose or not to use force feedback or auditory cues in their VE manipulation applications (Table 2). The table also suggests areas where future research would be of interest to designers of VEs.
